title: 103_s2127
content:
The "Railroad Grade Crossing Safety Act of 1994" establishes standards for grade crossing signal devices and state highway safety management systems. The Act aims to improve safety at public railroad-highway grade crossings by allocating responsibility for the selection and installation of signal devices. The Secretary of Transportation will amend regulations to require State highway safety management systems to include public railroad-highway grade crossing closure plans and policies limiting new at-grade crossings. The Secretary of Transportation must amend regulations within one year of this Act to include public railroad-highway grade crossing closure plans and policies limiting new at-grade crossings. SEC. 4. EMERGENCY NOTIFICATION OF GRADE CROSSING PROBLEMS. The Secretary of Transportation must establish an emergency notification system using a toll-free telephone number for reporting safety issues at railroad-highway grade crossings. Railroads will be required to publicly display information about the system at each crossing. The Secretary of Transportation must establish an emergency notification system with a toll-free telephone number for reporting safety issues at railroad-highway grade crossings. Railroads must display information publicly at each crossing, including instructions on how to use the system and a unique identifying number assigned by the Secretary. Judicial proceedings cannot hold any entity liable for damages related to actions taken under this section. The Secretary of Transportation is authorized to establish an emergency notification system for reporting safety issues at railroad-highway grade crossings. Funding of $1,000,000 for fiscal year 1995, $500,000 for fiscal year 1996, and $500,000 for fiscal year 1997 is allocated. Non-Federal sources must cover at least 30% of the system's costs. SEC. 5. OPERATION LIFESAVER. Authorization of Appropriations for Operation Lifesaver, Inc. is set at $300,000 for fiscal year 1995, $500,000 for fiscal year 1996, and $750,000 for fiscal year 1997. The Secretary of Transportation is limited to providing financial assistance not exceeding $150,000 unless it is for a specific national program aimed at reducing fatalities and injuries at railroad crossings and trespassing incidents. The program must receive at least 30 percent of its funding from non-Federal sources, such as States and railroads. SEC. 6. INTELLIGENT VEHICLE-HIGHWAY SYSTEMS: The Secretary of Transportation must ensure that the National Intelligent Vehicle-Highway Systems Program promotes safety at railroad-highway grade crossings. Two or more operational tests funded under the Act should enhance highway traffic and railroad safety.

SEC. 7. PENALTIES FOR CERTAIN GRADE CROSSING VIOLATIONS. The Secretary of Transportation must amend regulations to prohibit drivers of motor vehicles transporting hazardous materials or commercial motor vehicles from driving onto a railroad-highway grade crossing without sufficient space to drive through without stopping. Additionally, regulations under the Federal Railroad Safety Act of 1970 will be amended to address vandalism and trespassing. The Railroad Safety Act of 1970 (45 U.S.C. 431) allows for civil penalties for defacing or disabling signal systems at grade crossings and trespassing on railroad property. SEC. 8. VIOLATION OF GRADE CROSSING LAWS AND REGULATIONS. The Commercial Motor Vehicle Safety Act of 1986 is amended to include a new section on violation of grade crossing laws and regulations. The Secretary will establish regulations with sanctions and penalties for violations of laws and regulations regarding railroad-highway grade crossings by commercial motor vehicle operators. First violation results in a 90-day disqualification and a $1,000 civil penalty, while a second violation leads to disqualification. The regulations establish penalties for violations related to commercial motor vehicle operation. Violators face disqualification for 1-5 years and a $1,000 civil penalty. Employers allowing violations may be fined up to $10,000. State regulations are to be issued within five years. The Commercial Motor Vehicle Safety Act of 1986 is amended to include grade crossing regulations, and a technical amendment redesignates a section. SEC. 9. SAFETY ENFORCEMENT. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration and the Office of Motor Carrier Safety cooperate with various organizations to improve compliance and enforcement of laws and regulations related to railroad-highway grade crossings.
